docs.lead_paragraph: FOR a generation after it opened in 1940, and before it stumbled into a period of decline, the Parkchester apartment complex in the Bronx was a symbol of the American Dream, a meticulously planned community for 42,000 with open space and crisp well-maintained buildings. Last month, that dream came alive once more for Dulal Nandi, an immigrant from Bangladesh and an assistant manager at a Duane Reade drugstore in Manhattan. Just a few weeks ago, Mr. Nandi and wife, Supria, bought their first home, a one-bedroom condominium on the 10th floor of a red brick building at 1919 McGraw Avenue, just around the corner from a playground. They moved just in time: they are expecting their first child next month.

headline.main: Still a Beacon, Parkchester Climbs Back

docs.abstract: Turnaround is under way at Parkchester, 171-building Bronx complex, one of nation's first large-scale private housing developments; condo prices have risen and are at or above peak levels of 1980's; Community Preservation Corp, which took part in 1998 purchase of condominium sponsor's interest in project, has played key role in building political and civic support for $220 million renovation of apartments; is now beneficiary of turnaround, with value of its holdings rising; graph of apartment values; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A woman accused of murder because she refused a Caesarean section that might have saved her unborn twin rejected the prosecution's contention that she had wanted to avoid scarring. The woman, Melissa Ann Rowland, said that she was concerned about her recovery time and that doctors never told her she might need an emergency procedure. Ms. Rowland, 28, who has been jailed since mid-January on a child endangerment charge involving the surviving twin, said her other two young children, ages 7 and 9, were both delivered by C-section.

headline.main: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Denial In C-Section Murder Case

docs.abstract: Melissa Ann Rowland, Utah woman accused of murder because she refused Caesarean section that might have saved unborn twin, rejects prosecution's contention that she wanted to avoid scarring (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A woman was charged with murder because one of her twins was stillborn after she reportedly refused her doctors' advice to undergo a Caesarean section. Prosecutors in Salt Lake City said that the woman, Melissa Ann Rowland, 28, said that she would rather lose the babies than be scarred by the surgery. One twin survived delivery in January. Ms. Rowland is being held in jail on $250,000 bail. Mindy Sink (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Murder Charge Over Stillborn Twin

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A long article about teenage romance, sex and pregnancy and not a word about abortion (front page, March 7)! In fact, in 2000, a third of pregnancies among 15-to-19-year-olds ended in abortion. Because contraception sometimes fails, abortion is considered a crucial and normal part of women's reproductive lives everywhere else in the developed world.
docs.abstract: Judith Levine letter says March 7 article about teenage romance, sex and pregnancy did not mention that a third of pregnancies among 15-to-19-olds in 2000 ended in abortion; holds because contraception sometimes fails, abortion is considered a crucial and normal part of women's reproductive lives everwhere else in developed world

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: For once, I'd like to see some coverage of the many teenagers who, armed with knowledge and contraception, explore their sexuality while their peers pursue virginity (front page, March 7).
docs.abstract: Christopher Hannegan letter on March 7 article says that sex among teenagers is part of growing up and that government-sanctioned focus on abstinence may instill millions of teenagers with sexual hangups that will plague them into adulthood

docs.lead_paragraph: For a 30-year-old with breast cancer, the outlook was harsh. Though chemotherapy might cure her, it would almost certainly damage her ovaries and leave her unable to have children. Refusing to give up hope, she chose an experimental procedure that might offer her a chance of one day having a family. Before starting chemotherapy, she had an ovary removed and frozen.

headline.main: Thawed Ovary Tissue Yields Healthy Embryo

docs.abstract: Loss of fertility from chemotherapy is common problem for women of child-bearing years; Dr Kutluk H Oktay of New York Weill Cornell Medical Center leads team of doctors in experimental procedure that removes ovaries from patients and freezes them for possible future use; group, writing in journal Lancet, reports on first woman to have embryo created from egg derived from her own frozen and thawed ovarian tissue; embryo did not develop into pregnancy, but odds of in vitro fertilization resulting in pregnancy on one attempt with single egg are not high; Oktay is optimistic that technique could lead to preserved fertility for many women in future (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re: ''For Babies, Going With the Grain'' (Vital Signs, March 2): I am extremely pleased by the finding that the addition of folic acid to bread and other grains has cut by a third the number of babies at risk for neural tube defects. Still, it is worrying that the low-carbohydrate diet craze has prompted many women to abandon these foods.
docs.abstract: Dr Jennifer L Howse, March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation president, letter on March 2 article about bread enriched with folic acid holds that popular low-carbohydrate diet robs women of additional supplement; suggests all women who could get pregnant take multivitamin with folic acid (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Many women have trouble shedding extra pounds after giving birth. But a new study finds that fathers also tend to gain weight after babies arrive -- and the more children, the greater the couple's risk of becoming obese. The finding suggests that eating habits and exercise may have as much to do with postpartum weight gain as hormones or other physiological factors do, said Dr. Truls Ostbye of Duke University, the senior author of the study. Parents, especially those with more than one child, may simply not eat as well or exercise as much as they did before they had children, Dr. Ostbye said.

headline.main: New Babies Add to Fathers' Girth

docs.abstract: New study suggests that social, cultural or psychological factors contribute to weight gain after birth of baby, not just hormonal and physiological factors; study, led by Dr Truls Ostbye of Duke University, finds that fathers gain 4 percent of body weight on average for each child born and mothers gain 7 percent; drawing (S)
